text: Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time- Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: I thought that was concentrating on that bundle that was in the lumbar region. Doctor: Yep. It was. Patient: It wasn’t, it wasn’t throughout where I have cancer throughout the spine. Doctor: Well, it’s, it’s, kind of altogether. You know? So it’s the lumbar, it’s the lower lumbar is where your- Patient: Radiation treatment was. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Patient: So it wasn’t doing anything up here or the middle of the spine. Doctor: No. No. Right. And that would be true for proton. Protons are you know there’s a spot I want and- Patient: Site specific. Doctor: Very. So the question is do you color right up to the line you know with a two millimeter ballpoint pen or do you have a five millimeter ballpoint pen. So you’re trying to cut it out and draw an outline. You know? Will you get more precise? Yeah you might get more precise but is there any meaning to that for the patient. And that’s what we don’t know. So new stuff. I think we have to keep an eye on that technology to see what they think. Family Member: Mm Hmm.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be… Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think it’s going to come pretty quickly. So the company that our group because our group invented it. It’s a company in France, that is a very experienced company developing new uh radioactive things. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That company just got bought by N___ Patient: Oh. Doctor: for five billion dollars. So there’s now a kind of uh a big shift. So I think it’s going to happen. Patient: So it’s going to be? Doctor: But up until now, it’s been this kind of almost called hit or miss, and just because of the way we did things in the U.S., it hasn’t. It’s been very frustrating. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can’t tell ya. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, unless we stick a needle into the bone and say, “Does cancer come out?” Patient: Right. Doctor: Or is this just a hole there? And, so, part of me has to figure out from what you are saying is - is it better or not better. You know, what’s different? You know, clearly under here, I feel like a quarter. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Family Member: Do they die or are they just inhibited? Doctor: Yeah they like ninety nine percent die then maybe not one hundred precent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So that’s with the injection. Then there’s a little cylinder, a little flexible cylinder about this long – Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: - that can be implanted under the skin. Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: That lasts for a whole year so that you don’t have to get injections. Some people like that because it’s convenient. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have to go back and forth. But typical most common ways is to get an injection every twelve weeks which is like every three months. Patient: Right. Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Which was like thirty. Patient: That there was no, there was no connection to prostate cancer in my genetic history? Doctor: Yeah. So these, these thirty genes or so that they test for, which are kind of very important cancer genes, you didn’t have any mutations of them. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: The uh, so the apricot seed. There was thing called, laetrile. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows.

text: Family Member: So do you have any experience with the BET inhibitor? Have you seen it work or is it so new that you don’t really know? Doctor: I have experience with a different BET inhibitor. So not this particular one. (Coughs) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -was an injection type of BET inhibitor. This one is a pill. So I think uh, no I really don’t have too much experience with this particular one. The study just opened frankly – Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -- and now we have two or three people who will probably start right around the same time. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. There is the possibility of – obviously we’ll be monitoring your kidney function, liver function, all of that pretty closely and be monitoring you for any side effects. I mean you tell me more than what anybody knows about this medication sometimes. But uh for the most part it seems to have been okay tolerated in the very, very preliminary, very few patients that have been on it. Patient: What about the diabetes? How does that fit in to this discussion? Doctor: We will have to see if it affects sugars and then accordingly adjust your medications for the diabetes. But right now I don’t know for sure that it does or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be monitoring glucose every time anyway. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
